com.martinandersson.javaee.cdi.packaging

Class ImplicitPackageInvalidTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.cdi.packaging.ImplicitPackageInvalidTest

  • public class ImplicitPackageInvalidTest
extends Object
    This test will not package a beans.xml descriptor file in the deployment archive, meaning that the archive is an "implicit bean archive" in which only annotated beans are eligible for CDI management.

    If we try to use a bean that has no "bean defining annotations", what happens then?

    CDI 1.1, section 5.2.2 "Unsatisfied and ambiguous dependencies": 

    
     "If an unsatisfied or unresolvable ambiguous dependency exists, the
      container automatically detects the problem and treats it as a
      deployment problem."
    CDI 1.1, section 2.9 "Problems detected automatically by the container": 
    
      "Deployment problems [..] occur when there are problems resolving
       dependencies, or inconsistent specialization, in a particular
       deployment. If a deployment problem occurs, the container must throw a
       subclass of javax.enterprise.inject.spi.DeploymentException."
    So the specification is pretty clear. The deployment is not supposed to happen.

    The Arquillian @ShouldThrowException dilemma

    Inspecting the server logs after running this test reveal that both WildFly 8.1.0 and GlassFish 4.1 throw this exception (WildFly 8.2.0 and 9.0.0.CR2 won't pass this test): 
    
     org.jboss.weld.exceptions.DeploymentException.class
    ..which extend javax.enterprise.inject.spi.DeploymentException so this behavior are in compliance with the specification. Therefore, it would be great if we could specify the expected exception class in the value attribute of @ShouldThrowException. However, doing so make the client, that is Arquillian, go crazy, throwing: 
    
     org.jboss.arquillian.container.spi.client.container.DeploymentException.class
    ..which do not extend the CDI 1.1 defined DeploymentException. But that doesn't matter. Even if we were to specify the base class "Exception.class", then Arquillian would still fail the test with this message: 
    
     Cannot deploy: ImplicitPackageInvalidTest.war
    So the problem with the test in this case, according to Arquillian, is that the test which is not supposed to deploy didn't deploy (!).

    With that said, because further exception class specification display an Arquillian related problem, having a naked @ShouldThrowException will do since we know why and the why is exactly as expected.

    Results

    Work on GlassFish 4.1 and WildFly 8.1.0, but not WildFly 8.2.0 and 9.0.0.CR2. The problem seems to be that later WildFly versions do not discover non-public EJB classes?

    TODO: Report a bug.

    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)
